title: Question Time is coming to Sunderland: How can I get in the audience?
text:
Yes - you can apply on the BBC website right here . 
The form asks you for basic contact details and some political positions and preferences too as the BBC tries to select a blanced, representative audience for each show. 
Once you’ve filled the form in, you’ll go into a pool and will be contacted two or three days before the show if your application is successful. Who will be on the panel? 
Producers keep their cards close to the chest on the make-up of the panel but details should be announced after this coming Thursday’s show. 
There’s been a trend in recent series to try and secure local representation on the panel so Labour might put forward an MP from the region. 
None of Sunderland’s MPs hold a position in the shadow cabinet so Newcastle’s Chi Onwurah might be a smart bet. 
The Conservatives are likely to send a big hitter and probably one best placed to hammer home their Brexit strategy given Sunderland’s association with the vote. 
After that, it’s anyone’s guess at this stage. 
Possible picks would include North East mayoral hopeful Jeremy Middleton and Sunderland born ex-Apprentice star and entrepreneur Katie Bulmer Cooke. Read More Has Question Time come to Sunderland before? 
Question Time last came to Sunderland in June 2009. 
The programme was filmed at Nissan’s Sunderland plant in the Sports and Conference centre. 
The panel included Conservative MP Ken Clarke, who was then shadow business secretary, the then Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman, Ed Davey, Guardian columnist Polly Toynbee and broadcaster Esther Rantzen. Like us on Facebook
